About Palmerston North Hospital Emergency Department

Key information about our department, including staffing, service details, and operational overview.

docs.title: Department Overview
docs.text:
Palmerston North Hospital Emergency Department is a 24/7 emergency service providing care for the MidCentral District Health Board region.

  • Service Type

    • Mixed adult and paediatric emergency department
    • Level 2 trauma centre
    • Regional tertiary referral centre
    • 24-hour acute surgical service

  • Department Capacity

    • Approximately 45,000 presentations per year
    • Average 120-130 patients per day
    • Resuscitation, acute, sub-acute, and observation areas
    • Fast-track service for minor injuries

Triage Categories

The department uses the Australasian Triage Scale (ATS):

  • Category 1 - Immediate (life-threatening)
  • Category 2 - 10 minutes (imminently life-threatening)
  • Category 3 - 30 minutes (potentially life-threatening)
  • Category 4 - 60 minutes (potentially serious)
  • Category 5 - 120 minutes (less urgent)

docs.title: Discharging Patients
docs.text:
Safe Discharge Process

Guidelines for safely discharging patients from the Emergency Department.

docs.title: Clinical Coding
docs.text:
WebPAS Coding Requirements

Complete the clinical coding on WebPAS including:

  • Diagnosis - Primary presenting complaint and diagnosis
  • Treatments provided - All interventions and medications
  • Procedures performed - Any procedures done
  • Outcome - Discharged home, to care facility, etc.

Why This Matters

  • Accurate coding ensures correct funding
  • Tracks department activity and outcomes
  • Required for national data collection
  • Medicolegal record

docs.title: Clinical Notes
docs.text:
Complete Documentation

Your discharge notes should include:

  • History and examination findings
  • Investigation results and interpretation
  • Diagnosis or working diagnosis
  • Treatment provided
  • Discharge plan and safety netting
  • Follow-up arrangements
  • Information given to patient

docs.title: Discharge Summary
docs.text:
What to Include for Primary Care

Feed back relevant information to the GP/primary care:

  • Presenting complaint and ED diagnosis
  • Investigations performed and key results
  • Treatment given in ED
  • Medications prescribed - new or changed
  • Follow-up required or recommended
  • Safety netting advice given to patient

docs.title: Tone and Language
docs.text:
Collaborative Approach

Never tell primary care what to do

  • ❌ "The GP must arrange X-ray in 2 weeks"

  • ✅ "Suggest repeat X-ray in 2 weeks if symptoms persist"

  • ❌ "Start patient on this medication"

  • ✅ "Started on medication, may benefit from continuation if symptoms ongoing"

Suggest and advise - allow primary care to make their own decisions

docs.title: Medications Requiring Follow-up
docs.text:
Handover to GP

Where medications are likely to need continuing:

  • Note this clearly to the GP
  • Specify the duration of treatment started
  • Indicate if repeat prescription may be needed
  • Explain rationale for medication
  • Include any monitoring requirements

docs.title: Prescribing New Medications
docs.text:
Discharge Prescriptions

Provide any new medications the patient needs:

  • Appropriate quantity for duration of treatment
  • Clear dosing instructions
  • Indication on the label
  • Side effects discussed with patient

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
Record Keeping

  • Document medications prescribed
  • Include duration and follow-up instructions
  • Note what patient education was provided
  • Record if patient declined any medications

docs.title: Common Discharge Medications
docs.text:
• Analgesia

    • Appropriate to pain severity
    • Consider escalation ladder
    • Safety netting for side effects

  • Antibiotics

    • Clear duration and indication
    • Red flag symptoms to return
    • Complete the course advice

  • Chronic Medications

    • If new diagnosis requiring long-term treatment
    • Clearly communicate to GP
    • Arrange appropriate follow-up

docs.title: Communicate the Plan
docs.text:
Critical Communication

Make sure the nurse looking after the patient is aware of the plan:

  • Discharge destination - Home, care facility, etc.
  • Any final tasks needed - Medications, wound care, etc.
  • Medications prescribed - What needs to be dispensed
  • Follow-up arranged - Any appointments made
  • Special instructions - Mobility aids, wound care supplies, etc.

docs.title: Team Communication
docs.text:
Before You Leave

  • Update the nurse before you leave the department
  • Don't just update WebPAS and disappear
  • Check if nurse has any questions
  • Ensure patient is ready for discharge

docs.title: Cannula Check
docs.text:
Always Check for Cannulas Before Discharge

ALWAYS check for cannulas before discharging patients!!!

  • Remove unnecessary IV access
  • Document if deliberately left in place (and why)
  • Patient safety issue - retained cannulas cause harm
  • Check BOTH arms
  • Document cannula removal in notes

docs.title: Other Device Checks
docs.text:
Don't Forget

  • Urinary catheters - Should they stay or go?
  • ECG leads and monitors - Remove before discharge
  • Oxygen masks - Not needed if sats normal on air
  • ID bands - Should remain on until patient has left

docs.title: Safe Discharge Criteria
docs.text:
Is It Safe to Go Home?

Consider:

  • Clinically stable and improving
  • Appropriate investigations completed
  • Treatment initiated and effective
  • Safe environment to go to
  • Social support adequate
  • Patient understands the plan
  • Follow-up arranged where needed

docs.title: Safety Netting
docs.text:
Red Flag Advice

Always provide clear return instructions:

  • Specific symptoms to watch for
  • When to seek help urgently
  • Who to contact for advice
  • Timeframe for expected recovery
  • Written information where possible

docs.title: Follow-up Arrangements
docs.text:
• Hospital Follow-up

    • Outpatient appointments
    • ED re-check if needed
    • Specialty review
    • Book before discharge where possible

  • GP Follow-up

    • Routine wound checks
    • Repeat prescriptions
    • Ongoing management
    • Clearly communicate expectations to GP

  • Other Services

    • District nursing
    • Physiotherapy
    • Social services
    • Arrange or provide contact details

docs.title: Vulnerable Patients
docs.text:
Extra Considerations

For elderly, frail, or vulnerable patients:

  • Social assessment - Can they cope at home?
  • Mobility aids - Do they need equipment?
  • Support services - Does help need arranging?
  • Carer availability - Who will look after them?
  • Cognitive ability - Can they follow instructions?

docs.title: Paediatric Discharges
docs.text:
Children and Young People

  • Ensure parent/guardian understands the plan
  • Provide written information suitable for parents
  • Clear return advice for worried parents
  • Consider safeguarding where relevant

docs.title: Discharge Checklist
docs.text:
Before Patient Leaves

  • Clinical coding completed on WebPAS
  • Discharge summary sent to GP
  • Medications prescribed and dispensed
  • Patient given discharge instructions
  • Safety netting advice provided
  • Follow-up arranged where needed
  • Nursing team informed of discharge
  • Cannulas and devices removed
  • Patient able to mobilise safely (or transport arranged)
  • Patient has somewhere safe to go

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text:
Avoid These Mistakes

  • Discharging before investigation results available
  • Not providing adequate analgesia
  • Forgetting to remove cannulas
  • Not informing the nurse
  • Inadequate safety netting
  • Telling GP what to do rather than suggesting
  • Not documenting discharge discussion
  • Discharging patient who can't cope at home

docs.title: Clinical Documentation
docs.text:
Purpose of Documentation

Good documentation protects you, ensures continuity of care, and demonstrates your clinical reasoning. It should be complete but concise, showing an ongoing process of assessment and review.

docs.title: Initial Assessment Note
docs.text:
Use a consistent structure for your initial assessment:

Standard Structure

PC - Presenting Complaint

  • Brief summary of why they presented

HPC - History of Presenting Complaint

  • Detailed timeline and characteristics
  • Relevant positives and negatives

PMH - Past Medical History

  • Relevant medical conditions

SH - Social History

  • Living situation, support, functional status

DH & Allergies - Drug History and Allergies

  • Current medications
  • Known allergies and reactions

O/E - On Examination

  • Vital signs
  • Focused examination findings
  • Relevant systems

Impression

  • Your working diagnosis
  • Key differentials to consider

Plan

  • Investigations ordered
  • Treatment started
  • Next steps

docs.title: Critical Cases - A-E Structure
docs.text:
For resuscitation cases, you may use an A-E (ABCDE) structure instead:

Resus Documentation

A - Airway

  • Patency, protection, interventions

B - Breathing

  • Respiratory rate, O₂ sats, breath sounds, interventions

C - Circulation

  • HR, BP, perfusion, IV access, fluids

D - Disability

  • GCS, pupils, glucose, neurology

E - Exposure

  • Temperature, injuries, examination findings

This can be used for the whole note or just the examination section.

docs.title: Document at Each Stage
docs.text:
Don't Combine Everything Into One Note

Document contemporaneously at each stage of the patient journey:

  1. After initial review - Your assessment, impression, and plan
  2. After senior discussion - Who you spoke to, what was agreed
  3. After new information - Investigation results, clinical changes
  4. After plan changes - Why and what changed
  5. After referrals/handovers - Who accepted, what was discussed

docs.title: Brief Timestamped Updates
docs.text:
Multiple Entries Are Better

Add brief timestamped notes any time new information is added or the plan changes. Can be just one line:

✅ 1630 - Referred to medical reg (Dr Smith) - happy to see patient, asks for urine dip in interim

✅ 1715 - Bloods back: Hb 72, discussed with Dr Smith, transfusion commenced

✅ 1800 - Patient reviewed by medical team, accepted for admission

docs.title: Why Multiple Entries Matter
docs.text:
Timeline Protection

Multiple entries are much better than one single entry where the timeline cannot be picked out:

  • Gives a great deal of protection when something goes wrong
  • Shows an ongoing process of continual input and review
  • Demonstrates appropriate escalation and decision-making
  • Makes it easy to see what happened when

docs.title: Include Names and Roles
docs.text:
Always Document Who

Make sure to include names of people discussed with:

  • ✅ "Discussed with Dr Jones (ED Consultant) at 1400"
  • ✅ "Referred to Dr Smith (Medical Registrar)"
  • ✅ "Reviewed by nursing staff, plan communicated to RN Brown"

Not:

  • ❌ "Discussed with consultant"
  • ❌ "Referred to medical team"

docs.title: When Specifics Matter
docs.text:
Include Important Details

Some situations require specific detail:

  • Trauma - Mechanism, forces involved, specific injuries
  • Chest pain - Character, radiation, timing, exacerbating factors
  • Overdose - Substance, amount, time, intent
  • Procedures - Indication, consent, technique, complications
  • Safeguarding - Specific concerns, who notified

docs.title: Avoid Excessive Detail
docs.text:
Keep It Relevant

Too much detail just makes it harder to review a note:

  • ❌ "Patient states they had a headache which started on Tuesday morning at approximately 8:15am when they were having breakfast which consisted of toast and eggs..."

  • ✅ "Headache started 3 days ago, gradual onset, worsening, associated with photophobia"

Finding this balance takes time and experience - don't worry if you're not perfect initially.

docs.title: Documentation Tips
docs.text:
Good Documentation Practice

Be Complete But Concise

  • Include all relevant information
  • Omit irrelevant details
  • Use clear, professional language

Be Objective

  • Record what was said, seen, and done
  • Distinguish between facts and opinions
  • Document your clinical reasoning

Be Timely

  • Document as close to real-time as possible
  • Add timestamps to updates
  • Don't delay documentation to combine notes

Be Clear

  • Use standard medical abbreviations
  • Avoid ambiguous terms
  • Make your plan explicit

Be Professional

  • Legible writing (if handwritten)
  • Appropriate terminology
  • No criticism of colleagues or patients

docs.title: Medicolegal Considerations
docs.text:
Your Notes May Be Scrutinized

Remember that your documentation:

  • Is a legal document
  • May be reviewed in complaints or investigations
  • Demonstrates your clinical competence
  • Shows appropriate senior involvement
  • Proves informed decision-making

If it's not documented, it didn't happen

docs.title: Documentation Checklist
docs.text:
Before Moving On

  • Initial assessment documented using standard structure
  • Senior discussion documented with name and time
  • Investigation results reviewed and documented
  • Plan clearly stated
  • Any plan changes documented with reason
  • Referrals documented with who and when
  • Patient/family discussions documented
  • Timestamp on each entry
  • Your name clearly identifiable

docs.title: Common Documentation Mistakes
docs.text:
Avoid These

  • One massive combined note - Makes timeline unclear
  • No timestamps - Can't tell what happened when
  • No names - "Discussed with consultant" - which one?
  • Delayed documentation - Trying to remember hours later
  • Copying and pasting - May include irrelevant/incorrect information
  • Missing impressions - Just listing facts without interpretation
  • Vague plans - "Continue management" - what does that mean?
  • No follow-up - Initial note but no updates as situation evolves

docs.title: Example Documentation
docs.text:
Good Documentation Example

1400 - Initial Assessment

PC: Chest pain

HPC: 45M with 2 hour history of central chest pain, crushing in nature, radiating to left arm. Started at rest. Associated with nausea and sweating. No previous cardiac history.

PMH: Hypertension, T2DM DH: Metformin, Ramipril. NKDA SH: Smoker 20/day, works as builder

O/E: Looks unwell, sweaty Obs: HR 92, BP 145/85, Sats 96% RA, RR 18, Temp 36.8 CVS: HS I+II+0, no murmurs Chest: Clear

Impression: ? Acute coronary syndrome

Plan: ECG (shows inferior STEMI), aspirin 300mg given, clopidogrel 300mg given, GTN spray, morphine 5mg IV, discussed with cardiology for primary PCI

1415 - Senior Discussion

Discussed with Dr Brown (ED Consultant). Agrees STEMI. Cardiology contacted (Dr White), patient accepted for immediate cath lab. Pre-PCI bloods sent.

1430 - Update

Bloods back: Troponin 2400, otherwise unremarkable. Patient stable, pain improved with GTN. Cath lab ready, porter called.

1445 - Handover

Patient transferred to cath lab with RN Green. Verbal handover given to cardiology team.

docs.title: Emergency Department Overview
docs.text:
Welcome to Palmerston North Hospital Emergency Department

An overview of our department layout, zones, and key facilities to help you navigate and understand our working environment.

docs.title: Department Zones
docs.text:
Our Emergency Department is divided into several clinical zones:

  • Resuscitation Area

    High-acuity patients requiring immediate intervention and close monitoring.

    • Full monitoring and resuscitation equipment
    • Direct access for ambulance arrivals
    • Critically unwell patients

  • Acute Assessment Area

    Moderate to high-acuity patients requiring assessment and stabilization.

    • Urgent care and treatment
    • Monitoring facilities
    • Close to nursing station

  • Sub-Acute Area

    Lower-acuity patients with straightforward presentations.

    • Fast-track patients
    • Minor injuries and illnesses
    • Quicker turnover

  • EDOA

    Emergency Department Observation Area for short-stay patients.

    • Extended observation (<24 hours)
    • Treatment completion
    • Awaiting investigations or specialist review

docs.title: Entry Points
docs.text:
• Ambulance Entrance

    • Direct access to Resuscitation Area
    • Dedicated bay for ambulance arrivals
    • Emergency access for time-critical patients

  • Walk-in Entrance

    • Main ED entrance for self-presenting patients
    • Triage desk for initial assessment
    • Waiting area for patients and families

docs.title: Patient Flow
docs.text:
Typical Patient Journey

  1. Arrival - Ambulance or walk-in
  2. Triage - Initial assessment and priority allocation
  3. Registration - Administrative details
  4. Clinical area - Allocated based on acuity
  5. Assessment - Medical review and investigations
  6. Treatment - Interventions and management
  7. Disposition - Discharge, admission, or transfer

Structured handovers ensure continuity of care and maintain situational awareness across the department. The incoming EPIC leads the handover process.

docs.title: EPIC-Led Handover
docs.text:
The incoming EPIC leads the handover process to ensure:

  • Complete overview of the department
  • All patients progressing appropriately
  • No patients missed or forgotten
  • Clear priorities for the incoming shift
  • Situational awareness across the team

Handover Process

The incoming EPIC will systematically run through every patient assigned to an emergency physician to ensure comprehensive coverage of all active cases.

docs.title: What to Include
docs.text:
Clarify Handover Status

Discuss all your patients during handover. If you're leaving, make it clear which patients have outstanding tasks requiring action versus those already referred or progressing without further input needed.

When handing over your patients:

Essential Information

Clinical Summary

  • Presenting complaint
  • Key findings and investigations
  • Working diagnosis

Current Status

  • Where are they in their ED journey?
  • Results pending?
  • Awaiting specialty review?

Outstanding Tasks

  • What needs to be done?
  • Any time-critical actions?
  • Expected disposition

docs.title: Priority Patients
docs.text:
Highlight These Patients

  • Deteriorating or potentially unstable
  • Time-critical tasks due soon
  • Complex social situations affecting disposition
  • Specialty referrals pending response
  • Outstanding critical results expected
  • Access block preventing admission
  • Safeguarding concerns

docs.title: Best Practice Tips
docs.text:
Effective Handover

  • Be on time - Handover starts promptly
  • Be prepared - Review your patients beforehand
  • Be concise - Focus on key information
  • Speak clearly - Ensure everyone can hear
  • Ask questions - If anything is unclear
  • Take notes - Document key points for incoming shift
  • Stay until complete - Don't leave before handover finishes unless asked to go and tidy up tasks

docs.title: After Handover
docs.text:
Once handover is complete:

  • Outgoing team - Finish off tasks that can be completed and tidy up patients (usually have time left in shift after handover)
  • Incoming team - Work in allocated areas and start seeing new patients unless otherwise directed
  • EPIC - Retains departmental overview and control

Assessment and Clinical Approach

Systematic approach to assessing patients and formulating your initial plan.

docs.title: Taking a Good History
docs.text:
Structured Approach

  • Presenting complaint - What brought them in?
  • History of presenting complaint - Details and timeline
  • Past medical history - Relevant conditions
  • Medications - Current medications and allergies
  • Social history - Living situation, support, functional status
  • Systems review - Relevant systems

Don't Skip the Basics

  • A thorough history is often more valuable than investigations
  • Let the patient tell their story
  • Ask clarifying questions
  • Document clearly

docs.title: Physical Examination
docs.text:
Focused but Thorough

  • Vital signs - Don't forget to check them
  • Focused examination - Based on presenting complaint
  • Relevant systems - Don't just examine the obvious
  • Safety netting - Look for red flags

docs.title: Ordering Investigations
docs.text:
Targeted Investigations

  • Review any relevant investigations already done
  • Order investigations where you are confident they are needed
  • Don't over-investigate - think about what will change management
  • Every investigation should answer a clinical question

docs.title: Common Investigations
docs.text:
• Bloods

    • FBC, U&E, LFT - as appropriate
    • Troponin - chest pain
    • Lactate - sepsis
    • Blood cultures - if febrile

  • Imaging

    • X-rays - fractures, chest pain, SOB
    • CT - head injury, PE, abdominal pain
    • Ultrasound - pregnancy, AAA, FAST

  • Bedside Tests

    • ECG - chest pain, palpitations, SOB
    • Urinalysis - abdominal pain, UTI symptoms
    • Blood glucose - altered consciousness
    • Pregnancy test - women of reproductive age

docs.title: Creating a Plan
docs.text:
Always Have Next Steps

Your plan should include:

  1. Investigations needed - What else do you need to know?
  2. Treatment started - What can you start now?
  3. Likely disposition - Discharge, admit, or uncertain?
  4. Time frame - When will you review?

It's OK to Be Wrong

  • Your initial plan may change with new information
  • Seniors expect you to have a plan, not necessarily the right one
  • The process of thinking through it is valuable
  • Be ready to adapt

docs.title: Claiming a Patient

Once you have selected a patient:

Put your name in the clinician section of WebPAS

docs.title: Presenting Patients
docs.text:
Structured Presentation

When presenting patients to senior clinicians, it's essential to follow a structured approach. This helps ensure clear communication and demonstrates your clinical reasoning.

Most Important Rule

Always have an impression and a plan - It doesn't matter if it's wrong! Seniors want to see your thinking process and help guide your clinical reasoning.

docs.title: Key Principles
docs.text:
Effective Patient Presentation

  • Structured - Use a consistent format (e.g., ISBAR)
  • Complete - Include all relevant clinical information
  • Concise - Focus on key points, avoid unnecessary detail
  • Clinical reasoning - Show your thought process
  • Have a plan - Even if you're unsure, suggest next steps

docs.title: ISBAR Framework
docs.text:
ISBAR - Structured Communication

I - Identify

  • Patient name, age, location
  • Your name and role

S - Situation

  • Brief summary of presenting complaint
  • Current clinical status

B - Background

  • Relevant medical history
  • Medications and allergies
  • Key investigation results

A - Assessment

  • Working diagnosis
  • Clinical impression

R - Recommendation

  • Outstanding tasks
  • Plan and follow-up required
  • Any concerns or safety issues

docs.title: When to Handover
docs.text:
• Shift changeover - End of your shift
  • Going to break - Extended breaks during shift
  • Transferring care - Patient moving to another area/team
  • Escalating concerns - When seeking senior input
  • Leaving department - Any time you're leaving the clinical area

docs.title: Red Flags in Handover
docs.text:
Don't Forget

  • Time-critical tasks - Procedures or reviews due soon
  • Deteriorating patients - Any concerning trends
  • Outstanding results - Tests pending that may change management
  • Communication issues - Family concerns, complex social situations
  • Safety alerts - Behavioural concerns, security issues

docs.title: Best Practice Tips
docs.text:
Presentation Excellence

  • Prepare beforehand - Review notes and results before presenting
  • Be concise - Respect the senior's time
  • State your impression - Even if uncertain, say what you think
  • Propose a plan - Show you've thought about next steps
  • Ask specific questions - "What would you do?" vs "I'm thinking X, does that sound reasonable?"
  • Be ready for teaching - Seniors may ask why you think something
  • Take notes - Write down their recommendations and reasoning
  • Document the discussion - Record who you spoke to, when, and the agreed plan

Don't Forget to Document

Always document your discussion with the senior in the patient notes. Include who you spoke to, when, and what was agreed.

Guidelines for referring patients who require admission to inpatient specialties.

docs.title: When to Refer
docs.text:
Early Referral

  • Once it has been decided that a patient needs admission, refer them
  • It is not necessary to await the results of all investigations before referring
  • Focus on critical tests that affect immediate management

docs.title: Investigations Before Referral
docs.text:
• Essential

    • Critical investigations that affect immediate care
    • Basic workup (bloods, imaging if urgent)
    • Any tests needed for safe transfer

  • Not Required

    • Complete diagnostic workup
    • Definitive treatment investigations
    • Tests that won't change immediate management

Start Treatment While Waiting

  • Begin appropriate treatment while awaiting specialty review
  • Don't delay referral for non-critical investigations
  • Specialty can request additional tests after acceptance

docs.title: Making Contact
docs.text:
Referral Process

  1. Identify the appropriate specialty
  2. Contact the receiving clinician for that specialty
  3. Present the patient clearly and concisely
  4. State your request - "I am referring this patient for admission"

docs.title: Key Information to Include
docs.text:
ISBAR Format for Referrals

Identify

  • Patient name, age, location
  • Your name and role

Situation

  • Presenting complaint
  • Working diagnosis
  • Clinical urgency

Background

  • Relevant medical history
  • Current medications
  • Allergies

Assessment

  • Vital signs and clinical state
  • Key examination findings
  • Investigation results

Recommendation

  • Why admission is needed
  • What you're asking for (admission, review, take over care)
  • Any time-critical issues

docs.title: Understanding Referral vs Consultation
docs.text:
Referring vs Asking for Advice

By default, you are NOT asking for advice - you are REFERRING a patient

  • The specialty to which you refer must accept the patient
  • They must arrange to review that patient
  • They take over responsibility for that patient's care

docs.title: When It's a Consultation (Not Referral)
docs.text:
• You're asking for specialist input but maintaining care
  • Patient may not need admission
  • Seeking advice on investigation or management
  • Be clear about what you're requesting

docs.title: If There Is Disagreement
docs.text:
Escalation Process

  1. Remain professional and document the conversation
  2. Clarify the disagreement - Is it about specialty allocation or admission need?
  3. Talk to your senior early - Don't try to resolve alone
  4. Consult the Allocation of Clinical Line Policy for guidance
  5. Escalate through appropriate channels if needed

docs.title: Common Disputes
docs.text:
• Specialty Allocation

    • Unclear which specialty should take the patient
    • Multiple specialties potentially involved
    • Solution: Refer to Allocation of Clinical Line Policy

  • Need for Admission

    • Specialty questions if admission needed
    • Suggestions for discharge with outpatient follow-up
    • Solution: Senior ED doctor involvement early

Documentation

  • Document who you spoke to and when
  • Record their response
  • Note any disagreements or conditions
  • Include senior involvement in decision making

docs.title: WebPAS Documentation
docs.text:

  • Time of referral call
  • Acceptance or any conditions
  • Expected time of review by specialty
  • Plan until reviewed

docs.title: Clinical Notes

  • Discussion with specialty team
  • Their acceptance and plan
  • Any interim management required
  • Handover details

docs.title: Building Good Relationships
docs.text:
Professional Communication

  • Be respectful and clear
  • Have all information ready before calling
  • Know your patient well
  • Accept feedback graciously
  • Learn from each interaction

docs.title: Common Pitfalls to Avoid
docs.text:
Don't...

  • Call without having assessed the patient first
  • Call without basic workup done (but don't wait for non-essential results)
  • Be vague about what you're asking for
  • Argue if you're uncertain - get senior help
  • Take "no" without senior involvement if patient genuinely needs admission

docs.title: Ongoing Responsibility
docs.text:
You're Still Responsible

Until the specialty has physically reviewed and accepted the patient:

  • Monitor the patient's condition
  • Escalate any deterioration immediately
  • Continue management as planned
  • Chase up if review delayed

docs.title: Top Ten Tips
docs.text:
Wisdom from Experience

Essential advice for working in the Emergency Department - simple principles that make a big difference.

docs.title: 1.  Respect Those Around You
docs.text:
Value Every Team Member

Respect those around you and value their opinion.

  • Nurses often know patients better than you
  • Allied health professionals are experts in their field
  • Patients know their own bodies
  • Your colleagues are there to help you

docs.title: 2.  The History Is Everything
docs.text:
Listen First

The history is everything.

Most diagnoses are made from the history alone. Examination and investigations confirm what you already suspect. Take the time to listen properly.

docs.title: 3.  Four Key Treatments
docs.text:
Think About These Four Things for Every Patient

There are 4 key treatments we give in the ED – think whether every patient you see needs any of these and you will save lives and relieve pain:

  1. Oxygen - Is the patient hypoxic?
  2. Fluids - Are they dehydrated or shocked?
  3. Analgesia - Are they in pain?
  4. Antibiotics - Do they have sepsis?

docs.title: 4.  Make a Difference
docs.text:
Every Patient Matters

Think "What difference have I made to this patient?"

Always try to make a difference, however small. It may "just" be getting them an extra blanket, but it matters to them.

docs.title: 5.  Remember They Don't Want to Be Here
docs.text:
Nobody Plans to Come to ED

No patient (almost) wants to be in the ED. They really don't.

It wasn't what they planned for their day. Be kind, be patient, and understand their frustration.

docs.title: 6.  Double Your Time for Difficult Interactions
docs.text:
When It's Hard, Try Harder

Spend twice as long with patients you don't like or don't get on with.

  • There's usually a reason for difficult behavior
  • Taking extra time often resolves conflict
  • You learn the most from challenging interactions
  • They need your help just as much as anyone else

docs.title: 7.  Look the Part
docs.text:
Professional Appearance Matters

Look the part. Be smart. Behave in the way you would expect anyone to behave towards you.

  • Patients judge your competence by your appearance
  • Professional behavior builds trust
  • Set the standard you expect from others

docs.title: 8.  Be On Time
docs.text:
Punctuality Is Respect

Be on time. Always. And leave on time if at all possible.

  • Your colleagues are relying on you
  • Being late affects patient care
  • Leaving on time protects your wellbeing
  • Handover properly so you can leave guilt-free

docs.title: 9.  Take Your Breaks
docs.text:
Self-Care Isn't Selfish

Take your breaks – eat when you can and drink water when you can't.

  • You can't look after patients if you don't look after yourself
  • Dehydration and hunger affect your decision-making
  • Regular breaks prevent burnout
  • Keep a water bottle with you

docs.title: 10.  Enjoy Yourself
docs.text:
Find the Joy

Enjoy yourself…

Emergency Medicine can be incredibly rewarding. Find moments of satisfaction in:

  • Making a difficult diagnosis
  • Relieving someone's pain
  • Learning something new
  • Working with a great team
  • Making a real difference to someone's life

If you're not finding any joy, talk to someone about it.

docs.title: The Most Important Thing
docs.text:
Remember

Every patient is someone's loved one. Treat them as you would want your own family treated.

docs.title: Working Up a Patient
docs.text:
Ongoing Patient Management

After your initial review and plan (with or without senior discussion), some patients will need ongoing workup in the department.

docs.title: Medications to Consider
docs.text:
Ensure Comfort and Treatment

Ensure patients have all medications they will need prescribed:

  • Analgesia - Don't leave patients in pain
  • Antiemetics - For nausea and vomiting
  • Antibiotics - If infection suspected or confirmed
  • Critical regular medications - Don't miss essential meds
  • Other symptom control - As appropriate

Don't Forget Regular Medications

  • Check medication history
  • Ensure time-critical medications are given (e.g., anticoagulants, anticonvulsants, insulin)
  • Don't assume nursing staff know about regular medications
  • Prescribe them clearly in MedChart

docs.title: Monitoring Progress
docs.text:
• Investigations

    • Keep an eye out for pending investigations
    • Review results as they become available
    • Plan to review patient as appropriate
    • Don't forget about patients waiting for results
    • Set reminders if needed

  • Clinical Review

    • Monitor for any deterioration
    • Be open to changing your plan with new information
    • Reassess if situation changes
    • Don't be wedded to your initial plan
    • Re-examine if clinical picture evolves

docs.title: Parallel Patient Management
docs.text:
You Don't Need to Wait

Where there is likely to be a wait before a patient is ready for disposition:

  • Pick up the next patient
  • You do not need to completely finish with one patient before starting on the next
  • Balance multiple patients simultaneously
  • Prioritize based on urgency and needs

docs.title: Juggling Priorities
docs.text:
Efficient Workflow

  • Use waiting time productively
  • While patient A waits for CT, see patient B
  • While patient B waits for bloods, review patient A's CT
  • Keep track of all your patients and their status
  • Don't lose track of anyone

docs.title: Keep the Team Informed
docs.text:
Essential Communication

  • Stay in touch with your senior to keep them up to date
  • Make sure the nursing staff are kept informed
  • Ensure the nurse in charge knows your plans
  • Update the team about any changes

docs.title: Why Communication Matters
docs.text:
• Senior Awareness

    • Seniors need to know what you're doing
    • They can help prioritize
    • They may have suggestions
    • They can escalate if needed

  • Nursing Team

    • Nurses need to know the plan
    • They can monitor the patient
    • They can alert you to changes
    • They know when investigations are ready

docs.title: Don't Wait Indefinitely
docs.text:
Always Have a Time Limit

Always have a time-limited plan in mind

  • Where investigation or management is likely to take more than a couple of hours:

    • It is probable that they should not remain under ED care
    • Talk to your senior if you are not sure
    • Always have a plan for progression in mind

  • ED is for acute assessment and stabilization, not prolonged workup

  • Consider if patient needs admission for ongoing management

docs.title: When to Escalate
docs.text:
Signs You Need to Change Course

  • Investigations taking longer than expected
  • Patient not improving as anticipated
  • Waiting more than 2-3 hours for next step
  • Becoming unclear about the plan
  • Patient deteriorating

Action: Discuss with your senior - patient may need admission or different approach

docs.title: Regular Review
docs.text:
Active Management

  • Set specific review times
  • Re-examine patients after key investigations
  • Look for clinical improvement or deterioration
  • Update your plan based on new information

docs.title: Be Flexible
docs.text:
Adapt Your Approach

  • Initial diagnosis may be wrong
  • New symptoms may emerge
  • Investigation results may be unexpected
  • Patient's condition may change

Don't be afraid to change your plan

docs.title: Red Flags During Workup
docs.text:
When to Escalate Immediately

  • Clinical deterioration - Worsening vital signs or consciousness
  • Unexpected investigation results - Critically abnormal findings
  • Diagnostic uncertainty - Unclear what's going on
  • Time dragging - Been working patient up for >2-3 hours
  • Resource constraints - Can't get investigations or specialist input needed

Get senior help early - don't struggle alone

docs.title: Workup Checklist
docs.text:
During Patient Workup

  • Essential medications prescribed (pain, nausea, antibiotics)
  • Regular medications continued
  • Investigations ordered and pending list checked
  • Time-limited plan established
  • Senior kept informed
  • Nursing staff aware of plan
  • Set review time based on investigation results
  • Other patients picked up while waiting
  • Patient reassessed after key interventions
  • Ready to move to disposition (discharge/refer)

docs.title: Calcium Calculator
docs.text:
Quick converter for calcium dosing. Enter the dose in any format (mmol, mg, or mL of either preparation) and see all equivalent doses.

Clinical Context

Two calcium formulations are commonly used in emergency medicine:

  • Calcium Gluconate 10%: 2.23 mmol Ca²⁺ (93 mg elemental) in 10 mL (0.223 mmol/mL)
  • Calcium Chloride 10%: 6.8 mmol Ca²⁺ (272 mg elemental) in 10 mL (0.68 mmol/mL)

Important: The mmol values refer to calcium ions (Ca²⁺), which is the clinically useful measure. The total compound mmol differs from the ion concentration.

Key Points

  • Calcium chloride contains ~3× more calcium ions per mL than calcium gluconate
  • Both are 10% w/v solutions (1 g of compound in 10 mL)
  • Calcium chloride is more caustic and should be given via central line when possible
  • Calcium gluconate is preferred for peripheral administration
  • The calculator accepts input in mmol Ca²⁺, mg elemental calcium, or mL of either preparation
  • Always verify doses and formulation before administration

docs.title: Magnesium Calculator
docs.text:
Quick converter for magnesium dosing. Convert between the common units used in clinical practice and calculate vials needed.

Clinical Context

MgSO₄ heptahydrate (MgSO₄·7H₂O) is the form listed in medchart, though most clinical guidelines simply refer to "magnesium" or "MgSO₄".

Standard preparation: 2 mmol/mL (10 mmol in 5 mL vial)

Key Conversions

  • 1 g MgSO₄·7H₂O ≈ 4 mmol Mg²⁺
  • % w/v = grams per 100 mL of solution
  • Always verify doses

docs.title: Anaphylaxis
docs.text:
Life-Threatening Emergency

Anaphylaxis is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction. Intramuscular adrenaline is the ONLY first-line treatment - give immediately if suspected. Do not delay for antihistamines or steroids. When in doubt, give adrenaline.

docs.title: Recognition
docs.text:
Diagnosis Criteria

Anaphylaxis is likely when all 3 criteria are met:

  1. Sudden onset and rapid progression of symptoms
  2. Life-threatening Airway and/or Breathing and/or Circulation problems
  3. Skin and/or mucosal changes (flushing, urticaria, angioedema)

docs.title: Additional Features
docs.text:
• Exposure to known allergen supports diagnosis but is NOT required
  • Skin changes alone are NOT a sign of anaphylaxis
  • Skin changes can be subtle or absent in up to 20% of reactions

docs.title: Common Triggers
docs.text:
• Foods (nuts, shellfish, eggs, milk)
  • Insect stings (bee, wasp)
  • Medications (antibiotics, NSAIDs, contrast)
  • Latex

docs.title: Key Treatment Points
docs.text:
Immediate Management

  1. Remove trigger if possible (stop infusion, remove stinger)
  2. Call for help - senior support
  3. Adrenaline IM - anterolateral thigh (vastus lateralis)
    • Adult: 500 micrograms (0.5mL of 1:1000)
    • Child >12 years: 500 micrograms (0.5mL of 1:1000)
    • Child 6-12 years: 300 micrograms (0.3mL of 1:1000)
    • Child <6 years: 150 micrograms (0.15mL of 1:1000)
  4. Position patient - lie flat with legs elevated (or comfortable if breathing difficult)
  5. High-flow oxygen - 15L/min via non-rebreather mask
  6. IV access and fluid resuscitation if shocked
  7. Repeat adrenaline every 5 minutes if no improvement

Second-Line Treatments

After adrenaline and resuscitation:

  • Antihistamine (chlorphenamine not available in NZ):
    • Cetirizine (oral - as per ALS guideline):
      • Adult/child >12 years: 10mg
      • Child 6-12 years: 5mg
      • Child 2-6 years: 2.5mg
    • Fexofenadine (oral alternative):
      • Adult/child >12 years: 180mg
      • Child 6-12 years: 120mg
  • Corticosteroid: Hydrocortisone (IM or slow IV)
    • Adult/child >12 years: 200mg
    • Child 6-12 years: 100mg
    • Child 1-6 years: 50mg

docs.title: Disposition
docs.text:
All Patients Require Observation

Observation time depends on severity and response to treatment

docs.title: Fast-Track Discharge (2 hours observation)
docs.text:
May consider after 2 hours from resolution if ALL of the following:

  • Good response (within 5-10 minutes) to a single dose of adrenaline given within 30 minutes of onset
  • Complete resolution of symptoms
  • Patient already has unused adrenaline auto-injectors and has been trained how to use them
  • Adequate supervision following discharge

docs.title: Standard Observation (Minimum 6 hours)
docs.text:
Recommended if:

  • 2 doses of IM adrenaline needed to treat reaction
  • Previous biphasic reaction

docs.title: Extended Observation (Minimum 12 hours)
docs.text:
Required if any one of the following:

  • Severe reaction requiring >2 doses of adrenaline
  • Patient has severe asthma or reaction involved severe respiratory compromise
  • Possibility of continuing absorption of allergen (e.g., slow-release medicines)
  • Patient presents late at night, or may not be able to respond to any deterioration
  • Patient in area where access to emergency care is difficult

docs.title: Discharge Planning
docs.text:
Before Discharge - Essential Actions

  1. Prescribe adrenaline auto-injector (2 devices)
    • Adult/child >30kg: EpiPen® 300 micrograms
    • Child 15-30kg: EpiPen Jr® 150 micrograms
  2. Demonstrate how to use auto-injector
  3. Written information on anaphylaxis and management
  4. Allergy action plan - what to do if reaction occurs
  5. Follow-up arranged with GP or allergy clinic
  6. Medical alert bracelet recommended
  7. Avoid identified trigger - clear written advice

docs.title: FORCE Trial: Torus Fractures
docs.text:
Evidence-Based Management

The FORCE trial (2022) demonstrated that removable splints are non-inferior to rigid casts for paediatric torus (buckle) fractures of the distal radius, with significantly better comfort and satisfaction.

docs.title: What is a Torus Fracture?
docs.text:
• Mechanism: Compression injury causing cortical buckling
  • Stability: Periosteum intact on tension side
  • Healing: Excellent, typically 3-4 weeks
  • Risk of displacement: Essentially zero

Not for Greenstick or Complete Fractures

This approach is only for torus (buckle) fractures. Other fracture patterns require appropriate immobilization.

docs.title: FORCE Trial Infographic
docs.text: Open full infographic in new tab

docs.title: Management Approach
docs.text:
Quick Decision

Torus fracture confirmed?

→ Optional removable splint

→ Regular analgesia

→ GP follow-up only

Confirm diagnosis: Torus fracture on X-ray (cortical buckle, no breach)

Immobilization: Optional removable splint for comfort only

  • Many children don't need any splint
  • If used: removable wrist splint for 2-3 weeks

Analgesia: Regular paracetamol ± ibuprofen as needed

Activity: Gentle use as comfort allows, avoid contact sports for 3-4 weeks

Follow-up: Routine GP follow-up, no fracture clinic needed

docs.text: FORCE Trial Main Page FORCE Trial Publication - The Lancet FORCE Trial Summary (DFTB) Starship Clinical Guideline

docs.title: Patient Communication
docs.text:
What to Tell Parents

Torus fractures are stable injuries that heal reliably:

  • No cast needed - a removable splint or bandage provides comfort while healing
  • Child can use the arm gently as comfort allows
  • Expect full recovery in 3-4 weeks
  • Return if increasing pain, swelling, or concerns

docs.title: Clinical Rationale
docs.text:
Trial Results at 6 weeks

966 children randomized to removable splint vs. rigid cast:

  • ✅ Significantly less pain with splints
  • ✅ Faster return to activities
  • ✅ No difference in re-fracture or complications
  • ✅ Higher satisfaction scores

docs.title: CT Head Indications
docs.text: NICE recommendations for CT head imaging in adults with head injury:

docs.title: Immediate CT (within 1 hour)
docs.text:
• GCS <13 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours post-injury
  • Suspected open or depressed skull fracture
  • Sign of basal skull fracture (haemotympanum, 'panda' eyes, CSF leak, Battle's sign)
  • Post-traumatic seizure
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • More than one episode of vomiting

docs.title: CT within 8 hours
docs.text:
• Loss of consciousness or amnesia AND any of:
    • Age ≥65 years
    • Dangerous mechanism (pedestrian struck by vehicle, occupant ejected from vehicle, fall from height >1 meter)
    • Coagulopathy (history of bleeding disorder, on anticoagulation)

Anticoagulation

Patients on anticoagulation (warfarin, DOACs) with even minor head injury should have low threshold for CT imaging.

docs.title: High-Risk Features
docs.text:
Immediate CT Required

Any of the following warrant urgent CT head:

  • GCS <14 (or GCS <15 if <1 year old)
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Signs of skull fracture or basal skull fracture
  • Altered mental state
  • Persistent vomiting (>3 episodes)
  • Post-traumatic seizure
  • Dangerous mechanism (high-speed motor vehicle accident, fall >1m if <2 years, fall >1.5m if ≥2 years)
  • Suspected non-accidental injury

docs.title: Admission for Observation
docs.text:
Consider admission for:

  • Any intracranial injury on CT
  • Persistent symptoms despite normal CT
  • Difficulty assessing child (e.g., very young, developmental delay)
  • Concern about caregiver supervision
  • Social concerns

docs.title: Discharge Criteria
docs.text:
Safe to discharge if:

  • Normal neurological examination
  • GCS 15
  • No high-risk features
  • Reliable caregiver
  • Easy access to ED if concerns

docs.title: Discharge Information
docs.text:
Patient Information Sheet

Provide written concussion advice to all caregivers at discharge.

Download Starship Concussion Advice Sheet

Head Injury Advice

Return immediately if:

  • Increased drowsiness or difficulty waking
  • Vomiting
  • Severe headache
  • Seizure or unusual movements
  • Weakness in arms or legs
  • Vision changes
  • Unusual behaviour or confusion
  • Clear fluid from nose or ears

docs.title: Return to Activity
docs.text:
Graduated return to activity after concussion:

  1. Complete rest - 24-48 hours
  2. Light activity - walking, light housework
  3. Moderate activity - jogging, light swimming
  4. Heavy non-contact - running, gym work
  5. Full contact practice
  6. Return to competition

Progress only if symptom-free at each stage. If symptoms return, drop back to previous level.

docs.title: Paediatric Fever
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Assessment and management of fever in children under 3 years of age.

Full Clinical Guideline (SharePoint)

docs.title: Key Principles
docs.text:
Important Points

  • ~3% of children <3 years with fever >38.9°C have serious bacterial infection
  • Young febrile children often present with non-specific changes in behaviour and appearance
  • Height of fever, rapidity of onset, and response to antipyretics are not good indicators of severity
  • Simple febrile convulsions are not associated with increased risk for serious sepsis
  • Senior medical staff are available to assist with clinical decision making

docs.title: Children Under 28 Days - Any Fever
docs.text:
High Risk Group

Bacterial infection in ~15% with possibility of rapidly progressive disease

Full sepsis work up required:

  • Urine (CSU, clean catch, or SPA - see MDHB-420)
  • Blood cultures
  • FBC
  • CSF (see contraindications below)
  • CXR

Admit for IV antibiotics:

Antibiotic Dose Frequency Amoxicillin 50 mg/kg/dose Q8H (1st week)Q6H (>1 week) Cefotaxime Load: 100 mg/kgThen: 50 mg/kg/dose Q12H (1st week)Q6H (>1 week)

docs.title: Children 28 Days to 3 Months - Any Fever
docs.text:
Risk: ~6% bacterial infection

If infant looks unwell:

Full sepsis screen: - Urine (CSU, clean catch, or SPA) - Blood cultures - FBC - CSF (see contraindications below) - CXR

Admit on IV antibiotics: - Amoxicillin (dose as above) - Ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg Q24H

If child looks well and feeding satisfactory: - FBC - Blood culture - Urine (CSU or clean catch) - CXR if respiratory signs present (grunting, tachypnoea, recession, O₂ requirement)

Consider antibiotics after results reviewed. If unsure, discuss with consultant.

docs.title: Children 3 Months to 3 Years - Fever ≥39°C
docs.text:
Clinical Judgement Required

Discuss with senior medical staff if uncertain how to proceed

docs.title: A. Clear Clinical Focus in Well-Appearing Child
docs.text:
Child is alert, responsive, and undistressed with obvious source of infection.

Management: Treat as clinically indicated. No laboratory investigation usually necessary.

docs.title: B. Child Appears Very Sick
docs.text:
Any of the following present: - Reduced conscious level - Poor perfusion - Petechial rash - Signs of cerebral irritation - "Looks very sick"

Full sepsis work up: - CXR - FBC - Blood culture - CSF (note contraindications below) - Urine culture

Admit for observation and IV antibiotics:

Antibiotic Dose Ceftriaxone Load: 100 mg/kg, then 100 mg/kg once daily or divided Q12H

Additional consideration: - Children with focal seizures, focal neurological abnormality, suspected encephalitis, or contact with active herpetic disease should also receive IV acyclovir

docs.title: C. Fever Without Focus - Not Severely Unwell
docs.text:
Rate of bacteraemia ~2% (mostly Strep. pneumoniae). Majority resolve spontaneously.

Important

  • FBC and CRP are not useful in determining risk of bacterial sepsis in acute presentation
  • UTI screening mandatory - prevalence 2-5%, most commonly missed bacterial diagnosis (see MDHB-420)

Investigations: - Urine culture (all patients) - Blood culture (consider in more unwell children) - CXR and CSF if indicated by history/examination - discuss with senior doctor

Special considerations: - Children on prior antibiotics are more likely to require CSF despite lack of meningeal signs - If drowsy after simple febrile seizure but otherwise well → short observation in CAU/ED may suffice - If discharged, provide febrile seizure handout (e.g., www.kidshealth.org.nz)

docs.title: Lumbar Puncture Contraindications
docs.text:
Do NOT perform LP if:

  • Evidence of raised ICP
  • GCS ≤12
  • Focal neurological signs
  • Cardiovascular instability
  • Widespread purpuric rash
  • Rapid clinical deterioration
